You hold your breath as Penelope places the collar around her neck, raising one eyebrow as she does so.

"See," she says. "Nothing even—"

It is at exactly that moment that you hear a tiny metallic 'click' as the clasp snaps into place. Suddenly, you feel an intense, unbearable pain, as if your very soul is being ripped from your body. Then in an instant it's over and you find yourself staring out across the parking lot, where students are arriving and going about their business as usual. That in itself isn't odd, but what is odd is that just a moment ago you'd been facing the other direction, toward the school.

Startled, you whip your head around to look for Penelope. As you do so, a tangle of light brown hair bounces across your vision. That's when it dawns on you. Gulping, you slowly bring your hands down to your chest, your heart sinking as they come into contact with two very large, very soft mounds that can only be Penelope's prodigious breasts. Reaching back through the tangled brown curls that surround your neck, you run your fingers along the smooth black leather of the Mind Control Collar.

It gave you control over Penelope's mind, all right—very, very direct control. Frantically scratching at the collar you scramble for the clasp—only to discover that it has somehow disappeared. The blood drains from your face as you remember the shopkeeper's warning: "Once that collar is around someone's neck, it can never be removed—the individual will be subject you your will for the rest of their natural life."

"No," you whisper to yourself in Penelope's too-high, squeaky voice. "No, no, no! I was just supposed to control her… not like this… not forever…."

As you stand there in shock, the first period bell rings and students begin jostling around you as they reluctantly make their way into the school. One of them, a football player, bumps into you as he passes. The force of the impact isn't tremendous, but it's just enough to upset your rigid pose. You let out a high-pitched squeal as you find yourself toppling forward, suddenly confronted by an unfamiliar center of gravity. As Penelope's generous assets smoosh painfully against the pavement, your vision suddenly blurs nearly beyond recognition. Afraid you may have a concussion, you lay still, waiting for your vision to clear. When it doesn't, you eventually realize why—your glasses have just come off. Once alerted to the problem, you manage to snatch the blocky frames and bring them back over your eyes, only to discover that one of the lenses now features a large crack.

Realizing that you can't simply lie down in the middle of the walkway without being trampled, you manage to push yourself to your knees and then, unsteadily, to your feet. It's difficult to stand normally with so much new weight pulling to your front, and you find yourself having to constantly roll your head and shoulders forward to keep your balance. Even moving slowly and carefully it is only with difficulty that you manage to walk up the stairs and into the school. You don't really come close to falling over again after that—you soon realize that Penelope's body isn't actually unstable, just unfamiliar—but your movements are still far from but graceful. Even without the balance issues, your masculine, high-impact gait is ill-suited to your new form. While you don't exactly have any comparative experience from this perspective, the bouncy jostling of Penelope's massive breasts under the sweatshirt seems to you excessive for a simple walk down the hall—and you don't seem to be the only one to have noticed. The oppressive stares are so disconcerting, in fact, that you have to duck into the bathroom to double-check that your new body is in fact wearing a bra. A quick peek proves that you are—a peach-colored one apparently sized 34E—but the revelation does little to put you at ease. The large bathroom mirrors only make things worse; even though you are by now well aware of exactly what has happened, it's still extremely unsettling to watch Penelope's reflection copy your movements. Hesitantly, you give a little wave as the dorky brunette in the mirror waves back.

"I'm… I'm really Penelope," you whisper, again unsettled by the pitch of your new voice.

You run a finger through your mousy hair, still transfixed by the image before you. After a moment, unable to restrain your curiosity, you hesitantly squeeze your large breasts through the sweatshirt. After a quick feel, though, you sheepishly snap your arms back to your sides and put aside indefinitely any 'exploration' beyond that—this is a public restroom, after all, and someone could stumble in at any moment. The last thing you need is for someone to see you fondling yourself in front of the mirror.

Instead, you decide to take decisive action. Exactly what decisive action, you haven't quite… decided. Yet. On the one hand, you're already late for class—if you are going to be forced to live Penelope's life forever you should probably try to avoid messing it up, which truancy would probably do. On the other hand, what if there's still a way out of this? What happened to the real Penelope and your old body, anyway? Maybe the crazy Wizard who sold you the Collar could set things right—or at least give you some answers.
123312.title: Trapped as Penelope!

choices: Accept the Wizard's offer; anything to get back to normal!
Refuse the Wizard's offer; you'll find your own way out of this mess!
1233122.content:
Keeping up appearances is all well and good, but you have no intention of remaining stuck as an embarassingly buxom nerdette one minute longer than you must. Thus, you make your way unsteadily out of the bathroom and back out to the parking lot, determined to find the old Wizard and set things right. Your own keys seem to have disappeared along with your original body, so you are forced to take Penelope's boxy little Volvo instead of your own car. The advantage of this is that the mirrors and so forth are already properly adjusted for your new stature, but you soon discover that no amount of adjustment will make the seatbelt rest comfortably across Penelope's generous bosom. No matter how you turn it, it soon ends up painfully pinching your skin at one point or another. In the end, you simply leave it unbuckled, safety be damned.

When you finally arrive at the mall you are suddenly confronted by a much bigger problem—the magic shop isn't there. In its place stand a Pretzel Palace, employees hawking twisted dough as though nothing was wrong. Frustrated, you storm up to the counter.

"Where's the magic shop that used to be here?" you demand in Penelope's squeaky little voice.

The pimple-faced cashier looks taken aback.

"I… we just sell pretzels," he stammers. "I don't know anything about any magic shop…."

You slam your tiny fists down on the counter.

"Not now, moron, yesterday! Where's the shop that was here this weekend?"

"I… I don’t know what you're talking about. Pretzel Palace has been here for almost seven months now…."

"Bullshit!" you scream, grabbing at the black 'mind control' collar fastened around your neck. "I bought this yesterday, right here, from some geezer in a bathrobe! Where is he? Where is the man in the bathrobe?"

"Please, just calm down, Miss. I don't know any—"

"Don't call me 'miss!'" you screech, face flush with rage. "It was right here! Right where you're standing!"

"Maybe you should talk with my manager…."

"No, just forget it. Thanks for nothing, you worthless sack of—"

Just then, an elderly man comes out of the back of Pretzel Palace. He's wearing their trademark yellow and white uniforms and a tiny plastic badge that says "Manager," but there's no mistaking that wizened frown. It's the Wizard.

"You…" you start.

"Now, now, no need to cause such a ruckus. Perhaps we should speak in private."

With a wave of his hand, the old man brings the chaos of the Mall to a stop. Shoppers freeze in mid stride, trash hangs suspended in the air above bins and the Wizard smiles faintly.
"That's better," he says. "Now, I take it you're not entirely satisfied with your purchase?"

"Satisfied?" you demand. "Satisfied? Do I look satisfied?"

You heft Penelope's ample assets for emphasis.

"Well, now, I think you'll find that the merchandise I sold you works exactly as advertised, does it not? Or are you claiming that you have not, in fact, received control over what this young woman's actions? Because I think you will find the evidence suggest otherwise."

"You know full well this isn't what you implied would happen! You deliberately misled me, old man!"

The wizard frowns.

"Be careful where you throw those accusations, young lady."

"I am not a young lady!"

The wizard merely raises an eyebrow. You pause to take a deep breath.

"Besides," you continue, "what happened to Penelope? Where's my old body?"

"She's safe," says the wizard. "No thanks to your efforts. As for your old body, well—perhaps something can be arranged."

"What are you talking about?" you demand.

"When you first came to me, you had no concern for anyone but yourself. I imagine that's still largely the case, but your inquiry after the welfare of your young friend demonstrates there may yet be some small shred of decency within you. Therefore, I propose a bargain. A test, if you will. If you can salvage this situation, turning your possession into a positive development for your friend Penelope, I will remove the collar and restore your original body to you."

"So the collar can be removed?"

"By sufficiently powerful magic, yes. But I will do this for you only if you complete the task I have set forth.

"How am I supposed to do that?"

The old man waves his hand, within which a small, neatly bound white book appears.

"This is your friend Penelope's diary. In it she has recorded not only the events of her daily life, but her aspirations, both petty and tremendous. If you can use this opportunity to further those goals, helping her to achieve that which she could not herself, I will consider your end of the bargain fulfilled. "

"And If I refuse?"
"Then I suggest you get comfortable using the toilet sitting down."
1233122.title: Confronting the Wizard.

choices: Join a club or after-school activity.
12331221.content:
Reluctantly, you take the diary from the Wizard's outstretched hand.

"All right," you say. "If it means I can get my own body back, I'll do it."

As soon as the white book slips from the old man's hand, the mall suddenly springs back to life. People are talking, shouting, and carrying on as if time hadn't just been frozen by a crazy old man disguised as a Pretzel Palace manager. Meanwhile, the wizard himself is nowhere to be seen, seeming to have popped out of existence the moment he released the diary.

Maneuvering to an unoccupied table in the food court, you crack open the diary and begin reading. A lot of it is mind-numbingly dull:

...Mr. Welles returned our papers on Magical Realism today. As usual, he requested permission to use mine as the example for next year's pupils. I'm thinking of asking him to write one of the instructor recommendation letters for my college applications. For the other, I can't decide between…


...Is my voice really that high? That Ashton girl called it "squeaky!" I'm not squeaky, am I? I'm certain I would have noticed something like that. At the very least, someone would have told me, wouldn't they? What does she know? Just because she's had years of vocal training doesn't mean everyone else is…


That kind of thing went on for pages at times, and didn't really help you in identifying "dreams and aspirations." Equally irrelevant—but much more interesting—were her occasional references to you. Unfortunately, they weren't always flattering:

...I caught Elliot staring at my boobs again today. I think he's planning on asking me to the spring formal. Why doesn't he ask that Kate girl he's always talking about? 'Kate and I used to do this; Kate and I always did that.' I don't know what I'll do if he does ask. He's a good friend, but he can't seem to take the hint that I'm not interested in him that way. Then again, who else is likely to ask me? It's not as if Andrew's ever going to notice me. Maybe I should just go with Elliot—I'll just have to make it clear that we'd be going as friends and nothing more. How hard can that be? I just hope…


...Elliot wanted me to come help him study for history again tonight—I lied and told him I was visiting my aunt. I like hanging out with Elliot, but when it comes to revision I don't think he even really tries. Maybe if he has to suffer through this test on his own he'll finally start to put a little effort into his schoolwork…


However, here and there you did manage to come across a couple of nuggets that look like the sort of thing the wizard meant:

...Why do those yearbook girls have to bounce around all day taking pictures of everyone but me? Don't they have classes to attend? It's not like I'm mean to anyone. Kyle, Matthew and Elliot all seem to like me—why am I so invisible to everyone else? It's not like I'm especially quiet; I participate in class discussions all the time. So why is it that as soon as the bell rings it's like I no longer exist? Why doesn't anyone notice me? For the past…


...I saw Ashton flirting with Andrew again today. How am I supposed to compete with that? Ashton's hair looks like something out of a Disney cartoon, always falling in perfect little red waves, never a strand out of place. He probably doesn't even know my name…


...Deferred! I can't believe they deferred me! I scored perfectly on the SAT—what more do they want? I talked to Mr. Welles about it, and he suggested that the admissions office may be looking for more 'well-rounded' applicants. Apparently the ability to put a ball through a hoop is as important as twelve years of practically perfect grades. I suppose that's not quite fair; Mr. Welles says it doesn't have to be a sports team—other clubs would qualify as well. Even so, it's not right for an institution that claims to be focused on academic…


That particular rant goes on for several pages. Leaning back in your chair, you ponder what to do next. The wizard's task certainly wouldn't be easy—Penelope's concerns seem fairly typical of a high school girl and to be honest you're probably even less qualified to tackle them than she was; if indeed they are achievable at all. Popularity, an Ivy League college, romance; why couldn't Penelope have aspired to play videogames or something? Still, it's your only shot, so it will just have to do. The question is—where to start?

You're hardly an expert in teenage girl drama, but after some brainstorming you do manage to come up with two possible courses of action. First, you figure many of Penelope's social issues are tied to her geeky image. Made-for-TV teen comedies suggest if you can shed that, you'll be one of the cool kids in no time. They also suggest that along the way you'll learn important lessons about the meaning of friendship or something equally trite, but that wasn't on Penelope's list and is therefore irrelevant to getting your body back.

On the other hand, you could just follow through with what Penelope apparently already had planned—you could join an after-school club in order to diversify her transcript. Surely getting accepted to a good college was more important in the long run than dates and peer pressure, right?
12331221.title: Reading Penelope's Diary.

123312212.content:
After some deliberation, you decide that Penelope probably knows best. Besides, joining a club has got to be orders of magnitude easier to accomplish than navigating the minefield of high-school girl-drama. All you have to do is put your name on the form and show up to a few meetings, right?

Unfortunately, even that doesn't prove to be quite as straightforward as you'd hoped. Popping into an Internet CafÃ© to check your school's website, you find to your dismay that most of the groups aren't even accepting new members this late in the year. All of your first choices—like film club, computer club, and gaming club—fall into this category. Even of those that are accepting new members, most are still impossibilities for one reason or another. Spanish club is accepting members, but Penelope only took Latin and you can barely master English. The Marching Band is taking on new members, but only those proficient in the trombone. Military Drill Team is actively recruiting but—oh, irony—only accepts guys. In fact, out of nearly sixty organizations, there are only two that are both still recruiting and might actually accept you.

One is the Model United Nations. You don't know a thing about international politics, or indeed even exactly what the Model United Nations does, but they're open to anyone. How hard could it be?

The other choice is Drama Club. While auditions for the school play are technically over, they're still accepting any girls who want to participate. For that, you can thank Ashton. With her lustrous red hair and silky soprano voice honed by years of vocal training, she's had the female lead in every single school production for the past three years. These days, so few girls even bother auditioning that Mr. Michaels—the theater director—usually has to either cut or combine several minor female roles. Of course, there's never any shortage of male actors competing to act opposite Ashton—a few out of genuine passion for the theater but most probably enticed by the prospect of long evenings alone in a rehearsal room with Ashton.

Neither sounds like much fun, but you should be able to suffer through, given the circumstances.
123312212.title: Choosing an Extra-Curricular Activity.

choices: Go after the rumored Genie bottle in Los Angeles.
12331222.content:
Slowly, you shake your head.

"No way, old man. Dealing with you is what got me into this mess in the first place. I'll handle this on my own, thank you very much."

The wizard sighs and retracts his hand.

"Very well. Goodbye, Elliot."

With no fanfare whatsoever, he disappears. As he does, the mall suddenly springs back to life, shoppers returning to their business as if nothing out of the ordinary had happened. Which, for them, you suppose it hasn't. Whatever. If the old man isn't going to help you, you'll just have to find another way to remove the accursed collar. You don't suppose it could simply be cut away, but the old wizard had mentioned that "powerful magic" could overcome the collar's effect. All you have to do is find some.

Unfortunately, finding powerful magic isn't as easy as it sounds—which, given how difficult it sounds, is saying something. However, you do stumble across a lead, if a distant one—a long and embarrassing call to the Better Business Bureau reveals another self-proclaimed 'magic shop' in town, this one apparently on a more permanent basis. Called "Reagents 'n Things," it's about half an hour's drive from the mall and you head over there as quickly as you can manage.

The similarities with the wizard's shop are striking. A small wooden door—albeit this one covered with anti-burglary bars—causes a tiny brass bell to chime as you enter the shop. As before, you seem to be the only customer, and the shopkeeper comes to address you personally. Unlike the wizard, though, this chap is rather young, boasting dreadlocks and appropriately new-age attire.

"Welcome, sister, to this humble house of the mystical arts. Rest easy, you are among friends here."

You don't see anyone but the shopkeeper to merit the pluralization of "friends," and don't appreciate being called 'sister,' but this guy may be your only hope so you grit your teeth and bear it.

"I'm looking for some kind of powerful magic," you say. "Do have anything like that?"

The young shopkeeper gestures to the walls and tables, most of which are lined with various baubles and crystals.

"Perhaps you could be more specific?" he asks. "I have many powerful artifacts here, from stones of warding to hand-crafted talismans of protection. Or perhaps you'd be interested in a spirit crystal? Such crystals are known to possess great healing properties."

You glance hesitantly around. None of that sounds like what you need.

"Actually, I was hoping you had some magical scissors or something. See, I just bought this collar from this old dude in a bathrobe, and now I can't—"

"You what?" interrupts the man, eyes wide. "You visited Spells R Us?"

He reaches forward and brushes the hair from your neck, gazing in wonder at the collar around your neck.

"You're into serious magic, young lady, serious magic indeed."

"Yeah, I noticed. So will any of these crystal things help me remove the collar?"

"What, this junk?" laughs the shopkeeper. "This stuff's not really magical. Just trinkets and baubles to amuse Goth kids and hippies. I do have a few genuine items in the back, but nothing to rival the Wizard's magic.

Your heart sinks.

"So you can't help me?" you ask.

The shopkeeper shakes his head.

"I'm afraid not," he says. "But I might be able to point you in the direction of someone who can."

The shopkeeper beckons you to sit.

"As I said, most of my clientele are posers and wannabes, but on occasion I do conduct business with the genuine article. One particular group came in a little while ago, looking for demon blood. Powerful stuff, that. I didn't have any, but I told them I'd let them know if I got any in stock."

He produces a small slip of paper with an address scrawled on it.

"This is where they said I could find them. I don't know what they're up to, but I could practically taste the magical energy coming off of them. Whatever they're doing, it's serious business—way out of my league. They might be able to help you, I don't know. Be careful, though. These are not people you want to trifle with, understand?"

You nod slowly.

"Is there any other way?" you ask.

The shopkeeper looks thoughtful for a moment, and then reluctantly nods.

"I've also heard a rumor—just a rumor, mind you—of a genuine genie bottle popping up somewhere in Los Angeles. Thing is, apparently whoever found it was some careful archeologist type, so he never touched it with his bare hands. So instead of granting the three wishes and disappearing like genies usually do, it's still there, still waiting for someone to touch it. If you can find that, you'll have that thing off your neck easy as cake. I don't care how powerful that choker is, it's no match for genie magic."

"Isn't that dangerous?" you ask. "Won't a genie try to trick me or twist my wish or something?

The shopkeeper shrugs.

"Oh, it's dangerous, sister," he says. "But that's how it always is with magic, you know? As for twisting your wish—well, that's possible. I imagine a genie could do whatever he damn well pleased. But most of them won't. No, your biggest problem is going to be getting the bottle in the first place. You think it'd still be up for grabs if any old schmuck could just drive to L.A. and take it? No way, sister. I don't know exactly where it is, but I guarantee somebody does. Probably several somebodies. People who will do anything—anything—to get those wishes for themselves."

He nods meaningfully, then passes you the slip of paper.

"Like I said, here's the address of those cultists. I wish I had something more specific for you on the L.A. Genie, but not many details make it this far north, you know? Whatever you choose, good luck. Just… if you get into trouble, don't tell anyone where you got your info, okay?"

Nodding, you thank the young shopkeeper and head out the door, brass bell chiming as you exit.

As you return to Penelope's car you struggle in vain to adjust the thin straps of her bra, which the effort of supporting her heavy bosom is causing to dig painfully into your shoulders. After a few minutes of movement fails to produce any lasting relief, you eventually give up and turn your attention to the more important problem—getting out of this stupid body altogether!

Thus, sitting alone in the parking lot, you ponder the young shopkeeper's suggestions. Should you drive south to Los Angeles in order to find and acquire the genie lamp, or stay in town and try to get help from the cultists?
12331222.title: Finding an Alternative Solution.

choices: Follow and observe them from a distance first.
123312221.content:
In the end, the decision is an easy one. Why drive all the way to Los Angeles searching for a bottle which may or may not even exist when the solution to your woes could be right here in town? No, the shopkeeper has given you a concrete lead and you're not about to waste it. Pulling the address card out of your pocket, you put Penelope's boxy little car in gear and head for the cultist's hideout.

And 'hideout' is indeed the appropriate term—the address leads you to a desolate machine shop on the outskirts of town, complete with boarded-up windows and long-since-faded graffiti. Indeed, you'd have been certain this place was still abandoned if not for the several sets of fresh tire tracks leading around the back of the facility. Parking Penelope's car some distance away, you silently observe the compound and ponder what to do next.

Though you're understandably eager to be free of the accursed collar and back in your own body, the unrelenting and increasingly uncomfortable tug of Penelope's generous assets is enough to give you pause. The mountains of flesh growing sweaty and itchy beneath your sweatshirt serve as an unfortunate reminder of your previous blundering encounter with matters of magic. You wonder if perhaps it would be wise to exercise a little more caution this time around. You could observe the cult from a distance first, become acquainted with the members and their customs before gradually insinuating yourself into their group.

Then again, such a process could easily take days—or longer. You don't exactly relish the thought of remaining trapped as a squeaky-voiced, topheavy nerdette for such an extended period of time, especially if such caution turns out to be unnecessary.
123312221.title: Finding the Cultists.

choices: Snoop around the Cultists' lair while they are gone.
1233122212.content:
With a resigned sigh that sends a jiggle through the twin mounds pushing outward under your sweatshirt, you decide that you've learned you lesson about rushing blindly into situations you don't fully understand. If you want to get back to normal—or at least avoid making things any worse—you're going to have to act a little less impulsively from now on. Therefore, eager as you are to return to your male body, you'll take the time to observe these so-called 'cultists' before making any rash decisions.

Predictably, exercising such caution turns out to be maddeningly uneventful; particularly compared with the frantic pace of the outlandish morning. For hours you sit staring silently at the machine shop, the monotony broken only by the painful pinching of Penelope's bra and your useless attempts to adjust it. The sun has almost disappeared over the horizon when, finally, something catches your eye. Sinking back in your chair to avoid notice, you watch with rapt attention as the cultists begin to file out of the machine shop.

They aren't exactly what you'd expected. They aren't wearing blood-red robes or mysterious cowls. They don't seem to be carrying any twisted daggers or mystical staffs. There is, in fact, nothing especially sinister about them at all. While they are dressed in stereotypically Gothic fashions, it's nothing more extreme or authentic than what you see people wearing at school. There are five of them, three guys and two girls. One by one they circle around the back of the building and one by one they emerge behind the wheel of surprisingly expensive automobiles. As you watch, the five luxury vehicles circle around on the overgrown grass in front of the machine shop and make their way onto the street, the single-file procession obviously headed downtown.

Quickly, your hand jumps to the ignition, but then you pause. You could follow the cultists, hopefully finally getting a chance to observe them as you'd planned, but you could also stay here and scope out their lair. You have to choose quickly—their tail lights are rapidly disappearing—but you may learn as much by snooping around here as you would by following them.
1233122212.title: Watching the Cultists.

12331222121.content:
Shaking your head, you put aside the notion of snooping around here. Even if you were able to find some occult artifacts, what then? If they were anything like the artifacts at the Wizard's shop, they'd probably look just like any ordinary object; besides, even if you could identify them you don't know enough about magic to understand what they were for. No, your best bet would be to follow the cultists themselves. Thus decided, you start Penelope's car and set about tailing the procession.

Luckily, this doesn't prove to be very difficult—the small convoy of luxury vehicles takes an essentially direct route back toward the center of down, and you're able to follow at a respectable distance without doing anything especially suspicious. Just to be safe, you continue driving once they reach their destination—some kind of club downtown—circling back and parking nearby only after the cultists have gone inside.

By the time you return, you realize you have a slight problem—you're not exactly dressed to go 'clubbing.' The club—which a large industrial-looking sign declared 'The Refinery'—doesn't have hordes of hopefuls stretching down the street, but there is a doorman. For a moment, you're afraid he won't let you in dressed as you are. In the end, though, while the bouncer does raise his eyebrows at your unkempt hair and baggy sweatshirt, he simply shakes his head and waves you in regardless.

Stepping inside, you discover the interior of the club to be everything you'd expect in a place like this—loud, dark, and crowded. All around you, young men and women laugh, drink, and dance in a wanton frenzy of sound and motion. You could hardly be more out of place. You wouldn't exactly describe this place as a 'gothic' club—this city isn't big enough to support an entire club exclusively geared towards such a specific market—but there's definitely a dark feel to the place. While only about a quarter of the patrons seem to be full-on Goths sporting the whole fishnets-and-black-lace thing, dark clothing does seem to be the norm; your shapeless grey sweatshirt attracts more than a few disdainful looks from better-dressed passers-by. Mostly, though, people just ignore you—which is fine by you. If nothing else, it makes it easier to focus on your objective: watching the cultists. For a moment you're worried that you might not be able to find them in the darkness—you never really got a great look at them to begin with—but eventually your eyes adjust and you spot the five serious-looking young people sitting by themselves in a circular booth on the far side of the club. That's them; you're sure of it. Gradually working your way over to that side of the club, you manage to slip into a chair at a nearby table from which you can observe the group without being seen.

The apparent leader of the group is a tall young man wearing some kind of long black coat. His multiple piercings and ashen-white skin would probably look rather silly in the harsh light of day, but here in the darkness of the club he actually looks rather frightening. To either side are two other men, a few years younger but similarly attired in black and chain. These two are obviously flunkies—while the tall leader speaks they merely nod enthusiastically as if every word is a priceless revelation. Finally, to the far right of the booth are the women. The first—a skinny girl with unnaturally sangria-red hair—is wearing a dark, silky dress and long black gloves extending up past her elbows. The second, a blonde even more emaciated than her companion, sports a long black skirt and an extremely low-cut camisole that displays her tiny breasts to scandalous advantage. Both the men and the women sport copious amounts of eyeliner, though only the leader and the blonde have visible piercings. None of them appear to be drinking—all are focused intently on their conversation.

"I'm just saying," says the redhead, "You know the ritual would be easier if we had more people."

"As I've said before," says the tall leader, "our current number will perfectly adequate once we acquire the last of the necessary reagents. In the interim we cannot afford to fritter away our time looking for new recruits—not at such a critical juncture. Our focus must remain exclusively on the completion of the rite."

"I know how important this is," says the redhead, "but you have to admit things have gotten a lot harder since we lost Fingers."

"Shit," says the blonde, "is that what we're calling it now? 'Lost?' We 'lost' Fingers? He fucking exploded! Ka-Boom! Did you guys miss that?"

"Fingers was fully aware of the potential risks when—" says the leader.

"Aware of the fucking risks?" says the blonde. "Don't give me that law school bullshit! Fingers was the best goddamn—"

"That is quite enough," says the leader, his tone icy. "We are all well aware of your involvement with Fingers. Romantic entanglements aside, I assure you that we all feel the same way. He was a friend, not to mention a valuable element of this circle. He will be missed. But it has been six weeks since the unfortunate incident, and your emotional outbursts are becoming a liability. If you cannot control yourself during a recreational outing, how can we expect you to uphold—"

"She's fine," says the redhead. "She'll be fine. But this is exactly what I'm talking about. Since we lost Fingers, we've all become stretched too thin. If we just had another—"

"Enough!" says the leader. "The entire rationale for this excursion was that you needed a respite from matters of import. The phrase you used was 'recharge your batteries,' was it not? I concur with that assessment, but if you are going to squander the entire evening bickering over recruitment policy we might as well return to the sanctum."

"So, what," says the blonde. "Stop fighting or you'll turn the fucking car around?"

"A crude phrasing," says the leader. "But not inaccurate. You came here to dance; I suggest you do so."

The blonde rolls her eyes, taking the redhead by the arm.

"C'mon, Red," she says, rising from the booth. "Boss wants us to dance."

With that, the two girls make their way out across the dance floor, where you can see them flitting through the crowd, dancing and talking with some of the more gothic-looking clubbers. It doesn't really look like they're flirting, though—this is something else, and the men at the table notice it too.

"Uh, boss," says one of the flunkies. "I think they're still looking for someone to replace Fingers."

"Yes," says the leader. "They are."

"Do you want us to stop them?"

"No."

"But…" says the flunky, "Didn't you just say…."

"Indeed," says the leader. "And because they believe me opposed to the idea, they will not waste my time with an unending procession of second-rate posers. They will seek to prove me wrong, and as such return to confront me only once they have located an individual I cannot possibly turn away. They will be critical in their screening, tireless in their hunt, and decisive in their final selection. Meanwhile, I am spared the headache of overseeing a process those two are perfectly capable of handling on their own."

"But," says the flunky, "you said this was a one-time thing. What if they don't find someone today?"

"I'd be most surprised if they did. But the girls are resourceful; I suspect that around this time tomorrow they shall approach me with an emergent situation that absolutely necessitates their presence at this establishment. Else, they will scurry away and return here in secret, providing us with some highly-plausible excuse for their absence. Either way, their search will continue."

The two flunkies nod excitedly, clearly smug about being selected to share in their idol's 'secret' plan. Neither seems to realize that the girls are actually the ones to have been given an important responsibility. A responsibility which, it seems, could be your ticket in.

The only question is: how do you make your move? Do you walk up to the girls now, or should you come back tomorrow night, better prepared?
12331222121.title: Following the Cultists to a Nightclub.

choices: Try to bluff your way into the group.
Tell the truth and ask for help.
123312221211.content:
As you watch the two girls work their way through the club, you realize that they obviously aren't waiting on your convenience. If you don't act now, they might well find their new member before you even get a chance to talk to them and you can't afford to let this opportunity slip away. Therefore, you rise from your seat and make your way over to the dance floor, placing yourself directly in the path of the two girls. You don't actually know how to dance—even in your own body—so you mostly just sway in place, bobbing your head to the music.

Unfortunately, the girls pass right by, approaching instead a somber-looking guy in a long, open trench coat. At first you think they might just have seen him first, but after three more selections it becomes clear that they're deliberately passing you over—they only seem interested in those patrons dressed in the dark, gothic fashion favored by their own group. Unfortunately, your baggy grey sweatshirt doesn't seem to meet their standards.

Not to be deterred, you opt to take the situation into your own hands. As soon as they finish their next conversation you walk up to them and grab their attention.

"Hey there," you say nervously. "What's up? Got a minute?"

The two girls turn in your direction, surveying you with obvious disdain.

"Damn," says the blonde. "Your voice is fucking annoying."

"Do you want something?" asks the redhead impatiently.

"Uh, I, just, um, noticed you were talking to people," you say.

"Ugh," says the blonde, "another fucking twilight groupie here to take in the local 'culture.' Piss off, geek. You don't want to fuck with us."

"No offense, princess," says the redhead, "but we are sort of in the middle of something. There are plenty of other people here, you know? Go introduce yourself or something."

The girls start to turn away; small talk is getting you nowhere. You decide to be direct.

"Look," you say. "You're looking for someone to join your little magic group, right? I want in."

Both girls turn suddenly serious.

"Who told you that?" asks the redhead. "Who told you about us?"

"And what the hell makes you think we'd invite some conformist bitch like you?" adds the blonde.

"I… uh…"

The two girls continue to glare. What should you say? Should you try to impress them by bluffing a proficiency in magic, or just tell the truth and ask for help?
123312221211.title: Approaching the Cultist Girls.

123312221212.content:
Eager as you are to be out of Penelope's body, the cult leader's words ring in your ears:

"They will be critical in their screening, tireless in their hunt and decisive in their final selection."

This is too important to mess up, and at the moment you doubt you'd make the cut. In fact, watching the girls make their way through the crowd, you realize that dressed as you are they probably wouldn't even have approached you—they seem to be interested only in those patrons dressed in the same dark, gothic fashion as they. Besides, even if you did get their attention, what could you possibly say to impress them enough to invite you to join? No, if you're to do this, you need time to prepare. The leader seemed confident the girls would be coming back here tomorrow night—that gives you twenty-four hours to get ready.

As you make your way out of the club and back to Penelope's car, you realize you have yet another problem; your family. Well, Penelope's family, actually; while your parents will surely be worried about their missing son, there's little you can do about that at the moment. Penelope's grandmother, on the other hand, will be expecting her home. As your quest would be much more complicated with West Lowery P.D. out searching for you, you decide it would probably be best for you to avoid getting Penelope listed as a missing person. Thus, you put the car in gear and make your way back out to the suburbs, bracing for confrontation.

A confrontation which turns out to be surprisingly brief; apparently, all those years of being a goody-two-shoe have banked some serious trust for Penelope. Where your parents would have grilled you like a freshly-caught salmon, Penelope's grandmother just accepts your flimsy excuses with a smile.

"Oh, I knew it had to be something like that," she says. "When the young lady from the school called, I told her right away you weren't the type of girl to play hooky. It just goes to show you how disconnected that administration is from their students. Why, I'll bet you all the real hooligans are getting away with their mischief clear-as-you-please, while the school is wasting its time harassing their star pupils because of a smudge on some form."

"Yup, Grams," you say. "It just goes to show."

After being treated to a delicious home-cooked meal—which is a true treat, because by this point you're absolutely famished—you make your way up to Penelope's room and start to get ready for bed. Doing so is nearly as satisfying as the meal; the feeling of relief when you finally release the clasp of Penelope's bra is palpable. It is quite literally as though a great weight has been lifted from your shoulders. By the time you're finished, you've never been so glad just to have a full stomach, an empty bladder and a soft bed.

Still, exhausted as you are from the day's events, you're also curious; you've never been in Penelope's room before—to say nothing of her body—so if you're interested this may be your best opportunity to do a little exploration of both.
123312221212.title: Waiting Until Tomorrow.

choices: Say, "Yup, Grams, I'll be 'tutoring' again.  You'd better call me in sick."
Say, "Nope, just a normal school day for me today."
1233122212121.content:
As Penelope, even falling asleep proves difficult; you usually sleep on your stomach, but now Penelope's enormous bustline makes the prone position painfully awkward. Lying on your side proves little better, and while the supine position at least relieves the pressure, the oppressive weight on your chest is still impossible to ignore. The unfamiliar surroundings don't help either. After what seems an eternity of twisting and turning, you do eventually manage to fall asleep, but even then it's more a matter of sheer exhaustion than actual comfort.

*****

When you awake to the blaring buzz of Penelope's radio alarm-clock, you're sore, angry—and initially quite confused. Once you recover your wits and remember the events of the previous day, you're mostly just sore and angry. Rolling lethargically out of bed, you fumble to silence the infernal machine, which you finally manage only by yanking the power cord from the wall. Yup, today is going to be another fantastic day.

Getting dressed, at least, is fairly simple; Penelope has even less fashion sense than you do. She doesn't literally wear the same clothes every day, but she might as well have; another sweatshirt—navy blue this time—and another pair of department-store jeans is all it takes to complete a totally in-character ensemble. The only real change you make from yesterday is the underwear; you select one of her F-cup bras, in the hope that the larger size will mean less of the painful pinching that so plagued you yesterday. Once dressed, you gather Penelope's things, eat a quick breakfast—the one advantage to all of this is that Penelope's grandmother is an amazing cook—and prepare to face the day.

"By the way, Penelope," asks Grams, "are you going to be tutoring at the middle-school again?"

She is referring, of course, to your hurried excuse for yesterday's absence.

"If so," she continues, "I'll just call in your absence so those ninnies at the office don't get confused this time. I swear, sometimes it's like that school is trying to hold back their gifted students. I mean, there you are, trying to do something good for the community, and meanwhile they're so caught up with bureaucratic nonsense that they can't even keep track of their own programs."
1233122212121.title: The Start of a Brand New Day

choices: Trick Ashton of Drama Club into wearing the Mind Control Collar.
Trick Lizzie, the school slut, into wearing the Mind Control Collar.
12332.content:
No matter how hard you try, you just can't bring yourself to put the collar on one of your friends, even if they do agree to it. No, you'll just have to trick someone else into wearing it. A couple of possibilities come to mind.

One obvious choice would be Ashton of the Drama Club. For one thing, she was stunningly gorgeous. Her deep red hair fell in perfect, gentle curves around her face and her eyes practically sparkled when she smiled. Everything about her was just perfect—her teeth, her nose, her skin—and she knew it. She hoped to become a Broadway actress one day and might even make it. It was well known that the theater director had long since stopped holding serious auditions for the female lead and instead chose productions specifically for Ashton. She would do anything for exposure, and would also almost certainly wear the collar if you told her that you were trying to sell it and needed someone to model it.

Illustration of Ashton  

The other choice would be Lizzie. Lizzie was… well, to put it bluntly, Lizzie was the school slut. She wasn't bad looking, even if she did wear way too much eyeliner and her deep brown bangs were teased into a perpetual state of 'sex hair.' Not that you spend much time looking above her neck; while her breasts are actually a little on the small side, her provocative outfits somehow always manage to produce—and display—an astonishing amount of cleavage. More to the point, she was one of the few girls at school who might actually want to wear the Collar simply as a fashion accessory. Plus, once she was under your control you could make her tell everyone that you were the best lover she'd ever had—given her 'extensive experience' with most of the popular guys, that would be quite the endorsement.

Illustration of Lizzie
12332.title: Deciding on a Target for the Collar.

123321.content:
In the end, there was never any real debate. Who else could you possibly choose over the gorgeous Ashton? You don't have any classes with her this semester, so it isn't until after school that you manage to catch up with her.

"Hey, Ashton," you say.

She turns to face you, surprised.

"Oh, hi," she says. "Elliot, is it? We had Spanish together, right?"

"Uh, yeah," you say, disappointed that she didn't seem to remember you very well. "I was actually hoping that you could do me a favor."

Ashton smiles one of her perfect smiles.

"Sure thing!" she says. "What do you need?"

"Well, I'm trying to sell this collar on E-bay, but I can't seem to make it look good just sitting on a table. I was hoping you'd be willing to model it so I could get a good close-up picture of the collar as it's meant to be seen."

Ashton smiles again, her eyes lighting up at the word 'model.'

"Of course!" she says. "I'd be happy to help. Do you want to do it now?"

"That'd be great," you say, handing her the collar.

Deftly reaching behind her head, she slips the collar around her neck and starts to fasten the clasp.

"All right," she says. "Do you have your camera with—"

It is at exactly that moment that you hear a tiny metallic 'click' as the clasp snaps into place. Suddenly, you feel an intense, unbearable pain, as if your very soul is being ripped from your body. Then, in an instant, it's over and you find yourself staring down the empty hallway, facing the opposite direction.

Startled, you whip your head around to look for Ashton. As you do, brilliant red bangs bounce across your vision. That's when it dawns on you. Gulping, you slowly bring your hands down to your chest, your heart sinking as they come into contact with two firm, shapely mounds that can only be Ashton's perfect breasts. Reaching through the silky red hair that cascades around your neck and shoulders, you run your fingers along the smooth black leather of the Mind Control Collar.

It gave you control over Ashton's mind, all right—very, very direct control. Frantically scratching at the collar you scramble for the clasp—only to discover that it has somehow disappeared. The blood drains from your face as you remember the shopkeeper's warning: "Once that collar is around someone's neck, it can never be removed—the individual will be subject you your will for the rest of their natural life."

"No," you mutter to yourself in Ashton's soft, melodious voice. "No, no, no! I was just supposed to control her… not like this… not forever…"

"Ashton!" someone shouts from down the hall. "What are you doing out there? Rehearsal starts in five minutes!"

Turning to face the source of the sound, you see that it's Mr. Michaels, the theater director.

Illustration  

"Come on Ash," he says. "We've got a lot of work to do today."

"I'm… I'm coming," you say.

Apparently satisfied, Mr. Michaels turns and heads into the theater, where he begins shouting theater-y things to the people inside.

Should you follow? Ashton seems to be expected, and the last thing you need right now is even more trouble. Then again, you have no idea what to do in a theatrical production, so participating might be even worse for you than skipping.
123321.title: Trapped as Ashton!

choices: Go home before anyone sees you.
123322.content:
You find Lizzie, after class, coming out from behind the bleachers, with some freshmen boy. She was licking off her lips when she saw you and you walked over. You put on your best game face, and talked smoothly. She said "What are you doing here?" You replied "Baby, I know you want me badly... to go die somewhere haha, but that's no way to talk to someone who is delivering a gift from the coolest guy in school, Matt."

She esclaimed "Matt bought me something?" You smile and wink in a direction where no one was at (kind of like what characters in movies do when they break the 'fourth wall') and you hand her the collar. She puts it on eagerly, and as she does, you feel a strange tingling sensation, and you black out. The next thing you know, you are facing in the opposite direction, looking at no one, with a puff of smoke dissipating around the spot your gaze met. You look down and see a pair of boobs, to your surprise. You reached up, with what you noticed were manicured hands, and squeezed the boobs only to realize that they were real, and that you were no longer a man.

You let out a yelp out of your soft, feminine face, to here a girly sound, and you reach into your panties to discover that you indeed had a vagina.
123322.title: Trick Lizzie, the school slut, into wearing the...

1233221.content:
You start feeling your breasts, it feels so good you wonder why girls dont do it all the time, this makes you wonder....

As if on cue, another guy in your grade comes up and says "hey Lizzie, you up for some fun?"

You're initially disgusted but curiosity gets the better of you, you stop groping yourself, and gently take hold of the boys erection through his pants and lead him under the bleachers.
1233221.title: Check out your new body

12333.content: Do you pick someone in the mall or somewhere else?
12333.title: Force the Mind Control Collar upon a stranger.

choices: Go home and start tomorrow while wondering what's in the box.
Head to the back to change.
Do something else (there's plenty of other possibilities)
124.content:
There is an aisle marked "Magical Apparel" that has various costumes all guaranteed to transform you to "experience the character for real." Some of those seem interesting as you walk along checking them out, but you pass on them for now. At the end of the aisle, you discover that you're back at the front of the store where you just started. You don't remember turning a corner or the aisle bending, and you look back down the aisle scratching your head then shrug.

Before you now is the table with the jewelry and gum along with a pair of glasses and a small, brightly colored, crystal loop with an even smaller arrow and plus sign in the middle. You check you watch and see it's almost five o'clock.

This place seems useless and to have wasted even more of your time causing you to have accomplished absolutely nothing today. As frustration builds up, you look around to make sure the old man has not come back then reach towards the table to swipe one of the items. Only when your hand latches onto something, it isn't what you expected.

"So, you need to get a job?"

The old man's voice startles you coming from above, and you tremble from being caught and look up. He seems to have materialized on a step-stool behind the main counter where he has just hung a sign that says: "Because I am a wizard."

"Ah, ... yeah. But how'd you know?"

The gentleman turns his head and points to the sign. The place and this ancient geezer is creepy enough without the fact this guy has some sort of real magical ability, as if that were even possible, or thinks he does.

"That and the fact you just picked up the help wanted sign."

You look down and see that is exactly what's in your hand. You look back at the table and are sure that this sign wasn't there before.

"So, you see now that your time in here hasn't been wasted. Besides, I'm sure you have an honest heart when not too stressed."

The hairs on your neck are tingling like he knew exactly what you had been planning, and you contemplate whether you even want to be a store clerk here.

"Of course you do. Besides, it's not just a clerk."

Caught completely off guard by his answering your thoughts, you respond in the best way you know how.

"Huh?"

The old man again turns and points up at the sign. Then after a proper pause, he comes back around with a flourish and continues.

"As an apprentice, you would obviously have to monitor sales, but also you will be "checking" the inventory to make sure it is properly marked and in working order. You must know and understand the merchandise and its use so that any customer gets what they deserve. That's why there is always a full money-back guarantee."

"So, like I get to play with these things." you say as you sign the application and hand it to him not even realizing you filled it out.

"My dear boy, you do not play with magic." he sternly retorts before slowly looking up in deep thought.

"This might not be so bad." you think. "Although it's probably just minimum wage. At least dad will be off my case about it."

"Sixteen seventy-three."

"Huh?" your lightening repartee repeats itself.

"Sixteen seventy-three, minimum apprentice wage per hour. ... Your dad will be very happy."

"How'd you ..."

Another flourish of his hand toward the sign.

"You can start now and get a few hours experience if you like. It will be more enlightening than your friends house hunting experience and put a little cash in your pocket."

As your mouth opens to utter your unique surprise word because of his inference to Kyle and Matthew, he merely points his finger up to the sign before you speak, and then continues.

"Now here at King Applied Magic Enterprises, you must be properly outfitted to ensure the best customer experience. Proper sales technique will require experience, so you wear this to entice young men like yourself to leave some money here in place of some merchandise."

As he scrambles underneath the counter searching for something, you get concerned you'll have to wear some dorky robe like his or a pointed hat. Fortunately, he comes back up and hands you a folded apron or the like with a small box on top of it.

"You can change in the back or you can start tomorrow after school."

Leaning over at you, his face goes seriously dark and evil, and in a deep gruffly whisper commands, "Do NOT open the box until you have the smock on." Then he pulls back and smiles straightening his robe and adds, " It's not dorky nor is there a hat. "

"But ..."

His finger points to the sign.
124.title: Looking around gets you hooked.

choices: Put on the name tag and head back for answers.
Toss the name tag and charge out to give him a piece of your mind.
Stay here and keep trying to change yourself back.
1242.content:
Figuring it's better to not continue this conversation but to get on and make a few bucks on a quiet Sunday evening, you stride back down the costume aisle until you reach a door at the end - a door that you're sure wasn't there before. The wood it's made of is rough cut, and it's set into a simulated old stone wall. A sign on it is in that medieval script reading "Authorized Subjects Only."

"This guy really goes for the whole effect. you think. "But if being the right image is what it takes to make this kind of dough, then I'm all for it."

Entering through the door, you find a stone storeroom with flickering lanterns. To each side are similar doors one with the same old script that says "Change Yeeself Within." You roll your eyes and go through to a small chamber, again of stone, which has a large hand hewn chair with lacy cushions of a pink, yellow and red design and a full length mirror held in place by heavy iron brackets. There's also a small table that you set the smock and box on while sighing, wondering about how intense this fantasy is going to get.

When you move the box to pick up the smock a note falls off that you retrieve and read.

"A good apprentice becomes completely immersed into the world at hand."
         signed "Because ..."

"Now that's just too freaking weird!"

Tossing it aside, you pick up the smock and see it is rather nondescript except for pink and yellow script letters stitched into the back: "K A M E." There's also a note attached that instructs you to remove outer garments before wearing. So you drop your jeans after removing your shoes and pull off the "T" then pull the smock over your head like a dress. There's a tingling as it slides over your body, but you figure it's just the coarse material it's made of. The thing fits oddly being loose at the top and bottom but cinched tight in the middle.

You shrug off the poor fit and open the box to see what appears to be a name tag, a very fancy one, that is partly under some material and only revealing the letters "Ell." Again, you wonder how this guy got your name on the tag and in the box, but you immediately look up and chuckle, "I know. Because ..."

Picking up the cloth wrapped item on top, you find a leather cord holding a small amulet with a crystal in the middle. It's more something that you think you'd see a girl wear but do remember pictures from your history book of men of this time often having similar jewelry. So you tie it round your neck. There's just enough cord so you don't choke yourself.

As you turn to reach back for the name tag, you become very dizzy and grab the arm of the chair to keep your balance while you close your eyes. There's no strength left in your legs, and your whole body starts to tingle again and get warm. Thinking you're going to faint, you turn yourself quickly so that you sit hard in the chair. Flashes of scenes and events like a rapid slide show or dream fly by too quick to focus on any one, but the theme seems to be medieval history and various items you saw in the store. You figure it was just something in that slice of pizza conjuring images in line with this whole bizarre situation.

In less than a minute, it fades as quick as it came. You take a deep breath and open your eyes to find a woman with long dark brown hair sitting in a chair staring back at you. She's wearing the same smock and has the same necklace but with a bright pink crystal. Closing your eyes again, hard, to rid your mind of this last remaining illusion, you blink a couple times towards the floor then look up only to see the woman partially obscured by something dangling in front of your eye. You reach up and pull aside some long hair as the woman in the mirror does the same.

"WHAT THE ..." you start to shout watching the woman move her lips in synch with you, but stop when the voice you hear is of a woman. Immediately you stare down at yourself to find the smock now filled out with a woman's chest. You slowly put your hands on them to be sure they're yours and discover - they are.

Instantly, a thought of terror shoots through your body, and you jump up and pull the bottom of the smock above your waist. You see nothing. Nothing! You slide one hand down and confirm by touch what your eyes behold. All your manhood has disappeared.

As you let the smock drop back, you think, "Maybe it's the amulet," and try to get the necklace off but can't undo the knot.

Frustrated by this, fear now sweeps through you, and you gaze into the eyes of your reflection while you step backwards just as she does as if either of you might escape or hide. On the second step, your leg collides with that table followed by the sound of something hitting the floor. A downward glance discovers the box with the name tag. Still mesmerized, you pick it up and glare at the full name now revealed. Not Elliot, but Elle.

Here you are, seemingly transformed into a girl by magic. The old guy said he was a wizard and that you had to be properly outfitted, but you don't know whether to just assume this is part of the job and put on the name tag or if something worse, an evil spell, has been cast upon you. A bit of anger now boils up in you.

That because-I'm-a-wizard has some real explaining to do!
1242.title: Changing for the job.

choices: there are customers waiting! - start your job!
12422.content: You storm outside to face your new boss, the wizard to have a honest word with him, but…
12422.title: Toss the name tag and charge out to give him a ...

choices: Still angry, you demand to go back where you know what it's like.
To be a powerful wizard would be awesome, & you agree to stay.
124221.content:
You are beyond angry as you toss the name tag aside and almost rip the chamber door off as you throw it open and look for the door back to the store. There are two doors that both look the same, heavy wood with large iron strap hinges. Since you weren't paying attention when you came in, you aren't sure which to take. This makes you fume even more, but you figure if the one you take isn't the store, you'll just go back to the other.

Attacking the door to your right reveals a dim aisle with light at the end. You stomp in and pull the door hard to slam it, but it takes an awful lot of your strength, more than you think it should which causes more festering in your attitude. After it bumps closed (not as satisfying a sound as you hoped), you charge down the aisle muttering curses until you enter a large area with several rough old tables and benches covered with large old books, bottles, jars with stoppers, as well as a couple bowls and quite a few candles in candle holders. High windows send shafts of light across the room, and there is a slight smell of sulfur among other pungent scents.

This obviously isn't the store nor out in the back corridors of the mall. Bewildered you glance all around, but no one is visible, so you move further in trying to find anyone. As your feet shuffle across the dusty stone floor, they create a swishing sound that echoes off the stone walls like people whispering. There's a table with several piles of bones including both human and animal skulls that seem to stare at you. It's really creepy and shivers run up and down through you. Instead of turning back, curiosity takes over sending you wandering about looking at the odd things trying to figure what this is and where.

From the looks of these surroundings, you could be in a building from the middle ages, perhaps a castle since a room this size and all the large stones would require great expense. But you were just in the mall, so walking out a door into a castle is just ridiculously impossible.

"There's no way!" you think while opening a large, leather-bound manuscript.

Suddenly, you are startled by a man's voice coming from behind you that is vaguely familiar.

"Magic is not ridiculous nor is anything impossible if it is used properly."

You literally jump and spin around to see a shadowy figure standing in a doorway. There's so much light behind, you can't see his features. Then you realize his comment is referring to your thoughts, but how?

"On the wall behind you." he says as he closes the door.

You slowly turn cautious that he isn't about to come at you (you are a girl now after all as you were reminded by your bouncing chest when you jumped). There mounted on the wall is a board with old script that says, "Because I am a wizard."

Immediately, you recognize that it is identical to what the old man in the store had hung, and the voice was obviously his, although it sounded much younger and energetic.

"B-b-b-but the store and how could ..."

"My dear, I know you can read." he says pointing again at the wall as he pushes by you and abruptly closes the manuscript. As he turns round to face you, you see the same features of the store proprietor but a much younger face than before.

"Since you did not wear the store name tag when you came out, you entered into King Applied's Majestic Empire. This is part of the King's castle about a dozen centuries earlier than before. It's where I teach young apprentices their duties and responsibilities in using applied magic, that is when they aren't performing their other duties in the castle. You, my young woman, are a wizard's apprentice and will spend the next year or so here learning and practicing the trade of wizardry while not occupied otherwise."

You stand there disbelieving any of this especially that you're stuck for a year as a woman in some castle a thousand years in the past. You close your eyes as if this is a dream and figure that there's gotta be a way to get back to normal.

"My dear girl, you are already normal. Above average even, and will be here with me for quite some time." he replies and smiles, almost leers, at you. After a pause and a sigh he continues, "After basic spells, you will taught to change into various outfits and alter facial features. 12512.content:
Grinning at your success, you slip around the corner and retrieve your prize from your pockets. You'd done it! Simple pack of gum or not, your heart is still racing. That was exhilarating!

Trying not to look suspicious, you survey your prize.

Some kind of imported gum, it looks like, judging by the lettering. Is that brand name in Cyrillic? It's hard to say, it definitely looks eastern European though. Fortunately, it's only the brand name that's in the strange script; the bulk of the text has been translated into English… poorly.

"Super Lucky SUCCESS CHEW!" boasts the label. "Now with new of strawberry tasting!!"

The "instructions" on the back are little better.

"Magic lucky success guaranteed! Chewing of five minutes, get you ten minutes SUPER success time! No think need, all winning all things from gum chew alone! Caution: care with gum chew decision exercise. Use not overmuch gum chew success. Side effects from use much not responsible!!"

Scratching your head, you do your best to piece together the broken English. From what you can gather, it's supposed to be "lucky" gum. Chew it for five minutes, and you'll succeed at stuff for 10 minutes. Then the rest is some warning about not chewing too much.

So… weird foreign lucky gum. Hardly a grand heist, but still kind of cool in a quirky way.

Shrugging, you pop one into your mouth. It is, as promised, strawberry flavored. A little oversweet for your tastes, but perhaps that's just the sweet, sweet taste of victory. You chuckle.

And, actually, perhaps it's just the rush of your antics, but you'd swear that after a few minutes you *do* feel a little luckier. Maybe…

"This is silly," you mutter, but nevertheless, you find yourself walking up to one of those little kiosks in the middle of the mall, boasting that you could win a car. Feeling foolish, you fill out the drawing slip, and slide it into the slot provided. No sooner have you done so, than a man saunters up and slaps the box closed.

"Just in time, kid," he says with a smile. "It's five o'clock; we're just about to start the drawing!"

Huh. That was lucky.

You turn around, and see a curious crowd gathering. The man dramatically removes the entry box, and shakes it into a large, glass ball, which he spins with gleeful abandon.

"Here we are, folks!" he says as the ball spins, scrambling the entries. Finally, the ball spins to a halt, and he reaches in to remove one card. "The winner of a brand new car is…. Elliot Barnes!"

Your jaw drops in shock. The gum falls to the floor, now drained of color. Your head reels as you raise your hand.

You just won a car.
